Todo: merge [RTL](RTL.html) [right-to-left](right-to-left.html) [mirrored](mirrored.html) rotated [reverse](reverse)d  


[Wanderwords](wanderwords) and Kulturwords often exhibit extended matches with permuted consonants.  
While permutations themselves can simply be genetic mutations of words, something deeper seems to go on.  
 One reason for perfectly reversed orthography might be that during the foundation period of writing the reading order of phrases and compound signs was not set in stone. Between cultures there might have been confusion between left to right and [right to left](right-to-left) readings.  

See rotated / [permuted](permuted.html) words  

[article](article.html) as [ortho](ortho.html)[cul](cul.html) orthographic little orientation a'rotation markers see [ma](ma.html)

Notably in [Sumerian](Sumerian.html) the micro etymology of compound characters reads right to left, even though the general reading direction is the opposite! Of the many examples here are some:

Many words are cognate if they are read right to left  
ğ“Šª ğ“‚§ ğ“‹´ ğ“‚¾  podesğ“ƒ€stamp

ğ“… Toth teacher immutable  

In a time when reading order was not settled these variants might have arisen via errors 'lost in translation', puns, consonant permutations or (less likely) : coincidence.  

According to Wikipedia Some [reverse](reverse)d forms may have arisen from taboos
